Five-year Accident History
During the preceding five years, there have been no accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.
Emergency Response Plan
Equistar's has a written emergency response plan that addresses steps and actions for accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan encompasses aspects of emergency response including first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas. Emergency response planning is coordinated with the Nueces County LEPC, the Refinery Terminal Fire Company, local law enforcement, the Corpus Christi Fire Department and area hospitals. In addition, the plan is routinely reviewed at least annually and updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our processes that would require a modified emergency response.
The Corpus Christi Complex has implemented an emergency equipment inspection, testing and maintenance program which ensures that emergency response equipment will operate properly when needed.
Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Equistar is working in conjunction with the Nueces County LEPC to increase public awareness and communication in the event of a chemical release. This includes a public education effort undertaken along with other Corpus Christi industries as well as improved electronic communications (such as text messages and automated phone calls) to promote rapid dissemination of information.

Facility incident reporting is consistent both with sustaining a culture where people are not penalized or disciplined for reporting an incident while complying with relevant Human Resources policies and procedures. 
Equistar investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in, an employee injury or upset release of a hazardous material. These investigations, using Apollo Root Cause Analysis or similar root cause investigation method, are conducted to identify the specific causes, as well as identify corrective actions to help prevent similar reoccurrences.
Employee Participation
Equistar believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort. Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation to the RMP rule in particular information resulting from process hazard analyses.
Equistar is a member of the OSHA Voluntary Protection Program. As a VPP Star Work Site, this facility has gone above and beyond the normal safety requirements to provide employees with a safe working environment.
Contractors
Equistar utilizes contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out. Equistar has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and processes. Resident contractors are trained and must comply with our procedures at a minimum. Pre-startup Reviews
The pre-start up safety review process and requirements are part of the Management of Change/Process Change Authorization procedure.  Pre-start up safety reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe and environmentally compliant startup prior to placing the modification into operation.  Following mechanical completion, and prior to start-up, a Pre-Start-Up Safety Review is required whenever physical changes to process or equipment is made.  For changes that cannot be installed without being immediately put in service (e.g. instrument range change, DCS control change) the pre-start up review and installation are done concurrently.  
Compliance Audits
Compliance audits are routinely conducted at the CCO facility to identify system improvement opportunities and incorporate applicable best practices.  Audits conducted at the site consist of internal self-assessments, corporate audits and third-party audits.  Additionally, the audits identify best practices to improve existing systems. As an OSHA VPP worksite, Equistar conducts annual audits. Corporate and site auditing standards and procedures, which covers numerous business aspects (RMP, maintenance, operations, safety, health & environmental, PSM, etc.) are audited on a routine schedule. Any identified corrective actions required as a result of the audits are inputted into an electronic corporate-wide tracking system to ensure adequate and timely completion and agreement with site Leadership. 
Incident Investigation

artup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved with the processes.
Training
Equistar has a training program in place to ensure that employees that are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes. New employees receive basic training in process operations followed by on-the-job supervision until they are deemed competent to work independently. Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.
Mechanical Integrity
Equistar carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper functions.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others; pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps. Maintenance is carried out by qualified personnel with training in maintenance procedures and practices. Furthermore, these personnel have specialized training as needed. Equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner. CCO also has a specific Reliability Department to focus on improving overall plant reliability and equipment integrity and lifespan.
Management of Change
CCO has an active management of change program with a written procedure. The purpose of this procedure is to ensure that any changes to process chemicals, process technology, process equipment, process procedures, process operating personnel, or facilities are adequately reviewed and given appropriate approval prior to the change being made, and to document approval of the change.  This procedure complies with OSHA rule 29CFR part 1910.119 regarding the Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals and EPA rule 40 CFR par 68 Risk Management Program.

The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
Equistar has taken the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR Part 68. This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with NFPA-58 Standard. A number of processes at Equistar are subject to the OSHA PSM standard under 29 CFR 1910.119.
The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program in place at Equistar.
Process Safety Information
Equistar maintains a record of written safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes. During periodic turnarounds and projects, enhancements are implemented to better ensure plant operations remain within specific operating parameters. These safeguards also further reduce the potential for catastrophic failures during periods of excursions outside parameters.
Process Hazard Analysis
Equistar conducts studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently. The methodology used to carry out these analyses is referred to as a unit PHA. The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated on an as needed basis. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
Equistar is committed to the principles and requirements of Responsible Care®. We conduct our business in a manner that protects the environment and provides for the safety and health of employees, contractors, customers and the public. CCO is a member of the OSHA Voluntary Protection Program. As a VPP Star Work Site, this facility has gone above and beyond the normal safety requirements to provide employees with a safe working environment.
The Corpus Christ Operations (“CCO”) is committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is inherent to a comprehensive accidental release prevention program that addresses areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at the site. 
The Corpus Christi Complex maintains a full time, dedicated emergency response team. If a release occurs, Refinery Terminal Fire Company (RTFC) and Equistar personnel are available to control and mitigate the effects of the release. The site also utilizes an electronic card reader access system, LENEL, which improves the accountability process for site personnel during an event. Equistar continues to take community concerns seriously, the site deploys instruments for continuous real-time ambient air monitoring around the facility when needed.  CCO utilizes and maintains a comprehensive Emergency Response Plan (ERP). The ERP is designed to the specific needs of the facility and  operations, and outlines the strategies and tactics that are to be implemented for emergency response.
